ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Calculus basics, and Perseverance over lack of understanding.
Introduction to basic forms of calculus.
I was re-exposed to basically all math and mathematical thinking--which I hadn't studied in three years, since High School.
Basic Calculus. How to calculate and apply derivatives in real world examples.
I feel like I understand the concepts behind derivatives and antiderivatives better
Basic calculus skills including how to compute integrals, derivatives, limits, etc.

I gained a deeper and stronger understanding on the foundations of calculus. I feel much more confident now about calculus topics that in the past I have failed to fully grasp. I also learned a lot about myself and my time management skills. I am excited to continue with Calculus 115 in the fall.
I developed a better conceptual understanding of calculus.
Basic calc skills
I became better at calculus and developed more insight about time management from the assignments.
Basic calculus
I learned most of the content that is in an intro to calculus course.
Critical thinking skills, and higher-level math abilities.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The grade feedback time was extremely lagged behind new assignments. So you don't really know how well you're understanding the topics before new ones come up.
Strengths are that it's well-organized. Weaknesses are that the class moved slow in the actual session.

I actually enjoyed learning math through the online format. I thought the course went a little fast and had too many problem sets, though they were necessary to ensure we keep up. I also didn't like how the final was worth so much of our final grade.

Strengths- the pre-class work and videos were helpful. The practice exams were also great tools. 

Weakness- the nature of the summer session means the class was very fast paced. Office hours could have also been more regular.

I wish the class didn't go as fast, but I don't really think that's possible without taking it during a normal semester. Most of my problems with the class came from the class being only 5 weeks long.

I believe the recorded lectures were more informative than the in-person lectures. I think the structure of the class was one where I did 90% of my learning on my own and not a ton in class, which I didn't find exactly to my liking. However, I do think one of the strengths was the workshops and the workshop instructor.

The strengths of the course were being able to have so many outside resources available to our disposal. For example, other than the textbook we had lecture videos, in class examples, more textbook work if we wanted and workshop practice on Friday. This allowed for a good amount of repetition to familiarize ourselves with topics. However, this course could be improved by switching the order of when we would watch lecture videos and when we would learn those same topics in class. I would have benefited more if new topics were introduced in class and then we got a chance to practice and further our understanding in the lecture videos, not the other way around.
More personal instructions
The course had a manageable workload and easy access to help. The lectures possibly could be improved (but they weren't bad).

There were pre-class assignments that helped show what the content presented that class would be and they served as a good introduction to the material as well as easy points to help you maintain your grade which I found to be a strength of the course in terms of supporting students. A weakness would be the format of the "workshop" section of the course where we students were sent out into breakout rooms to work on a challenging question. These just seemed unorganized and students were left to work on the questions for way too much time and had to wait for the professor to verify our work before being able to move on to the next questions. That was a third of all the classes so that was not fantastic.
The strengths of this course were an appropriate workload and expectations.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Depends, if they're a math major, no-take it in person. If they're econ or compsci major where they just need to get it out of the way quickly, yes.
I would recommend this course to another student who needs the basics of calculus.
I would only recommend this course for someone hoping to take higher level math classes and probably not as a stand-alone class.

Yes. It is important to gain the skill of mathematical thinking. The material is important but the way of thinking is much more valuable. This course does a great job introducing this way of thinking.
If you want to get the class out of the way before the semester begins, take the class. Just know that it's a lot of work and time that you might rather spend doing other things.
I think I would, but not fervently. I believe the recorded lectures are good enough on their own to deserve a recommendation.

Yes, I think if students already have a strong foundation in math this class would be very valuable to them to take over the summer. However, it is very fast paced so I would make sure that the student was comfortable learning a new topic almost every class.
No
I would recommend this course only to someone already interested in math.
If you're taking this course it is probably because it is a prerequisite to other courses, so it works fine as a course for that reason but I don't see why you would take it simply for fun.
Yes I would, I thought that taking this class over the summer was advantageous and taught very well.
